bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 27, 1947

div1.p: Kean sends Hench letters (not included) from Finlay and gives Hench a very positive description of Guiteras.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 27, 1947
div1.opener:
2804 N Street N. W.
Washington DC
27 Jan '47
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
Your note of the 24th came today and I
have read with much interest your very
tactful letters inclosed to Lambert and Dr. Brumby
I think it was very wise for you not to quote me
but to state as facts in your knowledge, those that
disproved G. L's assertions. I think you have
done a fine job - much better than any one
else in my knowledge could have done.
I am very grateful to you for the time and
work you have put on these letters when you are
over burdened with more important affairs.
You will be sorry to know that our good and ac-
complished friend Col. Joseph F. Siler is in Walter
Reed Hospital and we have been very anxious about
him. He had his prostate gland removed a week
ago. I suppose it was cancer but have not heard
it so stated. I hear that he is somewhat better
this morning and hope that he may continue
to improve. I am inclosing with this some old
letters which I have come across in looking
for other matters. The contents are not of special
interest but the writers wereare notable men.
It seems to me I heard you say once that you wanted
a letter of Dr Carlos J. Finley's. Dr. Juan Guiteras was
AC
K
also a very able and accomplished man and spoke
both English and Spanish like the scholar that he
was and with the most melodious voice I ever
heard. I met him some years before the Spanish war
when he was teaching pathology in Phila. and I
was stationed at St. Augustine Fla. In Habana
he was Secretary of the Yellow Fever Board of which Finlay
and Gorgas were members and was in the second
Intervention Director of the Hospital for contagious diseas-
es (Las Animas).

We are well here except our old Cook Elizabeth who
has given up her job. I dont think she is very sick
but she is always very solicitous about her aches and
pains. We are now just breaking in a successor who
lives near by and is recommended by Elizabeth.

I am sure that you and Mrs Hench must have had
a merry Christmas with your children about you.
It takes children in the house to make a really
merry Christmas. With cordial regards to Mrs
Hench I am always
div1.closer:
Your friend Sincerely J.R. Kean Letter of Finlay Feb 2, 1908 to Kean filed in Finlay file
